sections.title: Prescription-only injectables for facial muscle symptoms
sections.body: Used to ease clenching-related discomfort, tension headaches, or TMJ-associated muscle overactivity when conservative steps are not enough. Always assessment-led and medically framed.
bullets: Dosing planned for function and comfort, not cosmetic change
Follow-up to monitor effect and adjust safely

sections.title: Clear scope and protocols
items: Assessment includes history, medicines, muscle activity, and bite findings
Conservative measures such as guards and physiotherapy considered first
Documentation of batch numbers, sites, and doses for traceability
Emergency pathways in place for rare adverse events

sections.title: Therapeutic focus only
items: Not cosmetic-first treatment or trend-led toxin use
Not for lip volume, profile balancing, or purely aesthetic aims
Not provided without prior clinical assessment and consent
Not continued if benefits are unclear or risks outweigh gains

sections.title: Decide if medication is appropriate
sections.body: We discuss symptoms such as clenching, tension headaches, or muscle tenderness. Examination guides whether to proceed with injectables or continue conservative care. We explain limits, review points, and when not to treat.
bullets: Medical and dental history including contraindications
Muscle examination and, where relevant, bite assessment
Review of previous response to guards, exercises, or medication
Discussion of dosage, expected onset, and how we monitor effect
Safety netting covering when to pause or seek urgent help

sections.title: Patients with muscle-driven facial symptoms
items: Clenching or bruxism causing persistent muscle tension
Tension-type headaches linked to overactive jaw muscles
TMJ discomfort where muscles contribute to limited opening
Patients unsuitable for cosmetic toxin aims but appropriate for therapeutic dosing
People who understand the limits and temporary nature of medication

sections.title: Assess, treat cautiously, and review
items: Assessment and consent with documentation of findings
Conservative steps reinforced; proceed only if medication adds value
Measured dosing to targeted muscles using aseptic technique
Review at agreed intervals to monitor function and side effects
Adjust or pause treatment based on response and safety
sections.strapline: Treatment is paused or stopped if goals are not met or risks emerge.

sections.title: Look after treated areas
items: Follow written aftercare on hygiene, activity limits, and posture
Monitor for expected temporary effects such as mild tenderness
Contact us urgently if you notice significant weakness, visual symptoms, or spreading swelling
Reviews booked to check function, adjust dosing, or decide on further care

faqs.question: Is this the same as cosmetic toxin?
faqs.answer: The medicine is similar but the intent and dosing differ. Here it is used to reduce muscle overactivity affecting comfort or function, not to change appearance.

faqs.question: How long do effects last?
faqs.answer: Effects are temporary and reviewed regularly. Repeat dosing only happens when benefits outweigh risks and you remain clinically suitable.

faqs.question: Can I stop at any time?
faqs.answer: Yes. Treatment is paused if you prefer, if symptoms settle with conservative care, or if side effects occur.

faqs.question: Who should avoid this treatment?
faqs.answer: Patients with certain neuromuscular conditions, pregnancy, breastfeeding, or contraindicated medicines may not be suitable. We screen carefully before proceeding.

faqs.question: Do I still need a guard?
faqs.answer: Often yes. Guards and self-care remain important to protect teeth and joints even when injectables are used.

sections.title: Book a therapeutic injectable consultation
sections.body: Discuss whether prescription injectables are appropriate for your facial muscle symptoms. Safety, suitability, and conservative care come first.
